#  The Δ*S*-sentials of Calculating Entropy Changes

::: {style="text-align: center;"}
DOFPro Team
:::

![](../../DOFPro_D7_Black_Red_Flame_No_Background_Cropped.png){.absolute left="22%" top="-65%"}

## 

:::{style="font-size: 150px;"}
**The Second Law of Thermodynamics**
:::

* No apparatus can operate in such a way that its only effect (in system and surroundings) is to convert heat absorbed by a system completely into work.
* It is impossible by a cyclic process to convert the heat absorbed by a system completely into work.
* No process is possible which consists solely in the transfer of heat from one temperature level to a higher one.

##

:::{style="font-size: 135px;"}
**Mathematical Statement of the Second Law**
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

<center> $dW_{\mathrm{lost}} \geq 0$ </center>

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
or
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center> $\Delta S_{\mathrm{system}} + \Delta S_{\mathrm{surroundings}} \geq 0$ </center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
$S$ can be thought of as the reversible normalized heat transfer or as
the degree of randomness or disorder.
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
Remember:
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center> $\Delta S_{\mathrm{system}} \text{ or } \Delta S_{\mathrm{surroundings}}$ </center>
:::

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
can be less than zero. But
:::

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center> $\Delta S_{\mathrm{system}} + \Delta S_{\mathrm{surroundings}} \geq 0$ </center>
:::

##

:::{style="font-size: 145px;"}
**Calculation of ∆*S* for an ideal gas**
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

Assume closed system of $n$ moles initially at $T_1$, $P_1$ and finally at $T_2$,
$P_2$

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
First Law
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$dU = dQ + dW$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$d\hat{U} = \dfrac{dQ}{n} + \dfrac{dW}{n}$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
Now follow a reversible path (why?).
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$d\hat{U} = C_v dT$</center>
:::

## 

:::{style="font-size: 145px;"}
**Calculation of ∆*S* for an ideal gas (cont.)**
:::

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center>$dS = \dfrac{dQ}{T}\ $ or $\ Td\hat{S} = \dfrac{dQ}{n}$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center>$dW = -PdV\ $ or $\ \dfrac{dW}{n} = - P d\hat{V}$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
Combining
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center>$C_vdT = T d\hat{S} - P d\hat{V}$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 80px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center>$d\hat{S} = \dfrac{C_v}{T} dT + \dfrac{P}{T} d\hat{V} = \dfrac{C_v}{T} dT + \dfrac{R}{\hat{V}} d\hat{V}$</center>
:::

## 

:::{style="font-size: 145px;"}
**Calculation of ∆*S* for an ideal gas (cont.)**
:::

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
<center>$\Delta \hat{S} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_v}{T} dT + \int\limits_{\hat{V}_1}^{\hat{V}_1}\dfrac{R}{\hat{V}} d\hat{V} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_v}{T} dT + R \ln \dfrac{\hat{V}_2}{\hat{V}_1}$</center>

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
Alternatively
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
$\ \ \ \ \Delta \hat{S} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_v}{T} dT + R \ln \dfrac{\hat{V}_2}{\hat{V}_1} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_p - R}{T} dT + R \ln \dfrac{\hat{V}_2}{\hat{V}_1}$
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
$\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_p}{T} dT - \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{R}{T} dT + R \ln \dfrac{\hat{V}_2}{\hat{V}_1}$
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
$\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_p}{T} dT - R \ln \dfrac{T_2\hat{V}_1}{T_1\hat{V}_2} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_p}{T} dT - R \ln \dfrac{P_2}{P_1}$
:::

## Ideal Gas Example

Example: What is the minimum work required for an adiabatic
compressor to compress $10\ \mathrm{kg/s}$ of air from $2\ \mathrm{kPa}$ and $300\ \mathrm{K}$ to $6\ \mathrm{MPa}$ (Assume ideal gas, $C_p = (7 ⁄ 2)\mathrm{R}$ )?

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
**First Law (neglect kinetic & potential)**
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$\Delta \dot{H} = \dot{Q} + \dot{W}_s$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$\dot{m} \int_{T_1}^{T_2} C_p dT = \dot{W}_s = \dot{m} C_p \Delta T$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
**Second Law**
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$\Delta \dot{S}_\mathrm{surroundings} = 0$. Why?</center>
:::

## IG Example (cont.)

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

<center>$\Delta \dot{S}_\mathrm{air} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_p}{T} dT - R \ln \dfrac{P_2}{P_1} = C_p \ln \dfrac{T_2}{T_1} - R \ln \dfrac{P_2}{P_1}$</center> 

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
Minimum work for $\Delta \hat{S} = 0$
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$C_p \ln \dfrac{T_2}{T_1} = R \ln \dfrac{P_2}{P_1}$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$\dfrac{T_2}{T_1} = \left(\dfrac{P_2}{P_1}\right)^{\frac{R}{C_p}}$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$T_2 = T_1 \left(\dfrac{6000\ \mathrm{kPa}}{2\ \mathrm{kPa}}\right)^{2/7}$</center>
:::

## IG Example (cont.)

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
$\dot{W}_s = \dot{m} C_p \Delta T$
:::
:::{style="font-size: 80px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
:::{style="font-size: 90px;"}
$= \dfrac{1000\ \mathrm{g/s}}{29\ \mathrm{g/g-mol}}\left(\dfrac{7}{2}\right)(8.314\mathrm{ J/g-mol K})\left[\left(\dfrac{6000}{2}\right)^{2/7} - 1\right](300\ \mathrm{K})$
:::
:::
:::{style="font-size: 80px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
$=26.64\ \mathrm{MW}$
:::

## 

**Calculation of $\Delta S$ for substances other than ideal gases**

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$d\hat{S} = C_p \dfrac{dT}{T} - \dfrac{\partial \hat{V}}{\partial T} \bigg\vert_P dP$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
or
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$d\hat{S} = C_p \dfrac{dT}{T} - \beta \hat{V} dP$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
where the volume expansivity (like a thermal expansion coefficient) is
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$\beta \equiv \dfrac{1}{\hat{V}} \dfrac{\partial \hat{V}}{\partial T} \bigg\vert_P$.</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
It is usually small $( \approx 0)$ for things other than gases.
:::

## Integrating *C~p~*/*T*

Performing the integral:

:::{style="font-size: 80px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$C_p = a + b T +c T^2 + d T^3$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 80px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$\dfrac{C_p}{T} = \dfrac{a}{T} + b + c T + d T^2$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 80px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$\int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_p}{T} dT = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \left(\dfrac{a}{T} + b + c T + d T^2\right) dT$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 80px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$= a \ln \dfrac{T_2}{T_1} + b ( T_2 - T_1) + \dfrac{c}{2} (T_2^2 - T_1^2) + \dfrac{d}{3} (T_2^3-T_1^3)$</center>
:::

## 

But what if $C_p$ is in $^\circ\mathrm{C}$, and the integral must be in $\mathrm{K}$?
Review *The Most Annoying Equation Conversion* video and plug in

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$T(\mathrm{K})− 273.15 = T(\mathrm{K})− cf$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
for $T$. Then
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center>$C_p = a' + b' T +c' T^2 + d' T^3$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
where $T$ is in Kelvin and
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center>$a' = a - b \cdot cf + c \cdot cf^2 - d \cdot cf^3$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center>$b' = b - 2c \cdot cf + 3d \cdot cf^3$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center>$c' = c - 3d \cdot cf$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::
:::{.fragment}
<center>$d' = d$</center>
:::

## Summary

$\Delta S$ for a heat reservoir:

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$\Delta S = \dfrac{Q}{T}$</center>
:::

:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
$\Delta S$ for an ideal gas:
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$\Delta \hat{S} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_v}{T} dT + R \ln \dfrac{\hat{V}_2}{\hat{V}_1} = \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_p}{T} dT - R \ln \dfrac{P_2}{P_1}$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
$\Delta S$ for a liquid or solid:
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
<center>$d\hat{S} = C_p \dfrac{dT}{T} - \beta \hat{V} dP \approx C_p \dfrac{dT}{T},\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \Delta \hat{S} \approx \int\limits_{T_1}^{T_2} \dfrac{C_p}{T} dT$</center>
:::
:::{style="font-size: 40px;"}
<br/>
:::

:::{.fragment}
$\Delta S$ for water/steam: Use the steam tables.
:::

## The Takeaways

1. To calculate the change in entropy for a heat reservoir, calculate $Q$ over $T$.
2. To calculate the change in entropy for an ideal gas, either use the integral formula with $C_v$ over $T$ and $\hat{V}$ or the integral formula with $C_p$ over $T$ and $P$.
3. To calculate the approximate change in entropy for a liquid or a solid, integrate $C_p$ over $T$.
4. To calculate the change in entropy for steam or saturated liquid water, use the steam tables.
